elements.content: The porous materials are efficient storage and exchange systems of small molecules and ions. Some of the porous materials may be used as an efficient storage system of iodine. Herein, a honeycomb (hcb)-type 2D+2D (2D = two-dimensional), parallel polycatenated Porous Polycatenated Coordination Polymer (PPCP) {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1 (INH, isoniazid; H2BDC, terephthalic acid; DMF, dimethylformamide) is characterized that reversibly uptakes I2 from organic medium (more than 98%). The single-crystal X-ray structure determination reveals the CdIN2O3 distorted octahedral geometry, and the microporous channel (∼1.7 nm) is generated by polycatenation along with the supramolecular interaction. On thermal treatment at 120 °C the polymer, 1, loses solvents, while the crystalinity is reserved. The solvent-free activated state of the coordination polymer, [Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2] n , 1′, adsorbs N2, and the adsorption–desorption analysis displayed the increase in porosity to mesoporous range (∼14.7 nm) with very high specific Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area, which may be due to the rise in interparticle void space. Iodine (I2) sorption studies of mesoporous architecture of 1′ show high I2 removal efficiency (98.9%), which is revealed from the reversible iodine uptake kinetics study. Typically, uptake of three moles of I2 per unit cell associated with color change from colorless to brown is discernible from thermal analysis. Interestingly, the iodine-loaded polymer (I 2 @1′) shows ∼1.5 times enhancement in electrical conductivity compared to 1′ only. The optical band gap obtained from density functional theory (DFT) calculation and the experimental values are 1, 3.48 eV (DFT), 3.70 eV (experimental) and I 2 @1′, 3.19 eV (DFT), 3.50 eV (experimental). The lowering of band gap after I2 sorption is presumably due to the interaction of I2 with Cd–I (Cd–I···I–I) in hcb core, which was evidenced from Raman spectra analysis.

elements.content: A honeycomb PCP of {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1 (INH, isoniazid; H2BDC, terephthalic acid) is thermally activated to mesoporous 1′, which efficiently adsorbed I2 (98.9%) to form I 2 @1′ due to presence of Cd−I···I2 interaction, and mesoporous feature is established by N2 adsorption studies. The I 2 @1′ shows ∼1.5 times higher electrical conductivity and enhances photosensitivity than the pristine activated PCP, 1′.

elements.content: Isoniazid (INH) has two donor sites, namely, pyridyl-N and hydrazide-O,N-chelator, and becomes an excellent bridging ligand to form a coordination polymer . Porous coordination polymers (PCPs), owing to the high surface area and variable pore architecture, are valuable material in sorption and separation of gases, catalysis, fluorosensors, and drug delivery. The electrical conductivity of the coordination polymers is developing recently. To improve the electrical conductivity various modifications have been mooted in the design of PCPs, and some of these are the use of high H+ conducting organic ligands, inclusion of the protic guests into the microchannels, through the engineering of heterodomain crystal systems, use of redox noninnocent cations/anions, binding with conformationally stable organic linkers that have very high tolerance to external stimuli preferably magnetic and optical, encapsulation of iodine (I2, I3 –), etc. Iodine, an important trace element to human health, marine environments, and in organic synthesis as a catalyst, has recently been the focus of public issues because of the growth of the nuclear industry. Because of the extensive implementation of nuclear power (very high energy density, ∼500 million times higher than gasoline by volume), vast quantities of iodine radioisotopes are released in the environment, and radioactive I2 (123, 125, 129, 131I) has severe health risk to mammalians. Among various types of capturing systems like zeolites, chalcogels, microporous polymers, porous aromatic frameworks, and covalent or hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks, silver exchanged zeolites were found to be very promising materials as solid adsorbents for I2 capture. It is important to design selective metal-organic framework (MOF) comprising an appropriate active site that may absorb iodine effectively. It is demonstrated that polar cavity with electron-donating groups, for example, −OH and −NH2, normally improve iodine sorption efficiency, which leads to increased electrical conductivity. The metal–iodide (M-I) coordination bond(s) in the PCPs may enhance I2 capturing capacity via M–I···I2 binding, thus increasing the sorption amount for iodine. The releasing processes of iodine from the porous materials are also vital for use of iodine as medicine. Iodine and its radionuclides have been vastly used as 123I (t 1/2 = 13 h) in imaging thyroid glands, 131I (t 1/2 = 8 d) against cancer treatment, 125I (t 1/2 = 59 d) as a γ-emitting tag for proteins, 129I (t 1/2 = 15.7 million years) used for monitoring long-living environmental contaminants, etc. So, capturing, storing, and releasing of iodine by using PCPs are the growing fields of attention and have also been focused on.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Isoniazid (INH) has two donor sites, namely, pyridyl-N and hydrazide-O,N-chelator, and becomes an excellent bridging ligand to form a coordination polymer  .    Porous coordination polymers (PCPs), owing to the high surface area and variable pore architecture, are valuable material in sorption and separation of gases, catalysis, fluorosensors, and drug delivery. The electrical conductivity of the coordination polymers is developing recently. To improve the electrical conductivity various modifications have been mooted in the design of PCPs, and some of these are the use of high H+ conducting organic ligands, inclusion of the protic guests into the microchannels, through the engineering of heterodomain crystal systems, use of redox noninnocent cations/anions, binding with conformationally stable organic linkers that have very high tolerance to external stimuli preferably magnetic and optical, encapsulation of iodine (I2, I3 -), etc. Iodine, an important trace element to human health, marine environments, and in organic synthesis as a catalyst, has recently been the focus of public issues because of the growth of the nuclear industry. Because of the extensive implementation of nuclear power (very high energy density, ~500 million times higher than gasoline by volume), vast quantities of iodine radioisotopes are released in the environment, and radioactive I2 (123, 125, 129, 131I) has severe health risk to mammalians. Among various types of capturing systems like zeolites, chalcogels, microporous polymers, porous aromatic frameworks, and covalent or hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks, silver exchanged zeolites were found to be very promising materials as solid adsorbents for I2 capture. It is important to design selective metal-organic framework (MOF) comprising an appropriate active site that may absorb iodine effectively. It is demonstrated that polar cavity with electron-donating groups, for example, -OH and -NH2, normally improve iodine sorption efficiency, which leads to increased electrical conductivity. The metal-iodide (M-I) coordination bond(s) in the PCPs may enhance I2 capturing capacity via M-I⋅⋅⋅I2 binding, thus increasing the sorption amount for iodine. The releasing processes of iodine from the porous materials are also vital for use of iodine as medicine. Iodine and its radionuclides have been vastly used as 123I (t 1/2 = 13 h) in imaging thyroid glands, 131I (t 1/2 = 8 d) against cancer treatment, 125I (t 1/2 = 59 d) as a γ-emitting tag for proteins, 129I (t 1/2 = 15.7 million years) used for monitoring long-living environmental contaminants, etc. So, capturing, storing, and releasing of iodine by using PCPs are the growing fields of attention and have also been focused on.

elements.content: In this work, we synthesized a honeycomb (hcb)-type porous Cd­(II)-based 2D+2D structure (2D = two-dimensional), parallel polycatenated PCP with INH and terephthalic acid (H2BDC) as pillar-forming ligands, {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1 (DMF = dimethylformamide). The structural analysis shows polycatenation with a microporous channel (∼1.7 nm). With thermal treatment, the complex 1 was transformed to a robust solvent-free activated state, [Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2] n , 1′, and nitrogen adsorption–desorption analysis displayed mesoporous channel (∼14.7 nm) with a very high specific Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption analysis of the activated polymer (1′) showed high BET specific surface area with type IV isotherm partaking steep uptake of N2 at low pressure, indicating typical mesoporous nature, whereas initial uptake implies microporosity. The nature of porosity presumably originates from the interparticle voids, since the unit cell parameters are typically within the range of 2 nm. The compound is used to sorb iodine. The ease of reversible iodine sorption and desorption with the change from nonpolar to polar solvent has paramount importance for the application of this PCP. The I2-adsorbed PCP, that is, I 2 @1′, intriguingly showed 1.5 times enhanced electrical conductivity. In conjunction with the experiments, the quantum mechanical calculations (density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent (TD) DFT) were performed both for 1′, 3.48 eV and I 2 @1′, 3.19 eV to get insight into the band gap and band positions and to the origin of electrical conductivity.

elements.content: INH, H2BDC, and CdI2 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. and were used as received. All other chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and purchased from Merck and used without further purification. Microanalytical data (C, H, N) were collected on PerkinElmer 2400 CHNS/O elemental analyzer. Spectroscopic data were obtained using the following instruments: IR spectra (KBr disk, 4000–400 cm–1) from a PerkinElmer RX-1 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using a Pyris Diamond TG/DTA Instruments in the range of 30–600 °C. X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 surface area analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C). Prior to gas adsorption, sample was pretreated with dry methanol every 6 h for 2 d; every time, freshly dried solvent was used to remove the guests form the PCP, and then it was degassed at 120 °C for 4 h, where the sample was activated due to generation of the porosity. Raman spectra were obtained by using Triple Raman spectrometer (model: T64000, J-Y Horiba) with a 532 nm laser and an 1800 grooves/mm grating. Morphology and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses of compounds 1′ and I 2 @1′ were performed via field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; JEOL, JSM-6700F).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Methods

INH, H2BDC, and CdI2 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. and were used as received. All other chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and purchased from Merck and used without further purification. Microanalytical data (C, H, N) were collected on PerkinElmer 2400 CHNS/O elemental analyzer. Spectroscopic data were obtained using the following instruments: IR spectra (KBr disk, 4000-400 cm-1) from a PerkinElmer RX-1 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using a Pyris Diamond TG/DTA Instruments in the range of 30-600 °C. X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 surface area analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature (-196 °C). Prior to gas adsorption, sample was pretreated with dry methanol every 6 h for 2 d; every time, freshly dried solvent was used to remove the guests form the PCP, and then it was degassed at 120 °C for 4 h, where the sample was activated due to generation of the porosity. Raman spectra were obtained by using Triple Raman spectrometer (model: T64000, J-Y Horiba) with a 532 nm laser and an 1800 grooves/mm grating. Morphology and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses of compounds 1' and I  2  @1' were performed via field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; JEOL, JSM-6700F).

elements.content: To a methanol solution (10 mL) of INH (0.137 g, 1 mmol) was carefully layered by the help of DMF solvent the aqueous solution of (10 mL) of CdI2 (0.366 g, 1 mmol). H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was neutralized with Et3N solution (0.212 g, 2 mmol) and was injected cautiously over the isoniazid solution followed by DMF solvent to make an undisturbed layer. It was then allowed to diffuse for one week. The colorless needle-shaped crystals were deposited on the glass wall. The crystals were separated mechanically under a microscope, washed with a methanol and water (1:1) mixture, and dried. The yield of {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1, was 72% (0.039 g). Elemental analysis calculated for (C26H34Cd2I2N8O9) n (1): C, 28.88; H, 3.17; N, 10.36, Found: C, 28.82; H,3.11; N, 10.26%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1663, νas(COO−); 1380, νs(COO−). For electrospray ionization (ESI † ) data, see Figure S1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]⋅(2DMF)(H2O)}n, 1

To a methanol solution (10 mL) of INH (0.137 g, 1 mmol) was carefully layered by the help of DMF solvent the aqueous solution of (10 mL) of CdI2 (0.366 g, 1 mmol). H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was neutralized with Et3N solution (0.212 g, 2 mmol) and was injected cautiously over the isoniazid solution followed by DMF solvent to make an undisturbed layer. It was then allowed to diffuse for one week. The colorless needle-shaped crystals were deposited on the glass wall. The crystals were separated mechanically under a microscope, washed with a methanol and water (1:1) mixture, and dried. The yield of {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]⋅(2DMF)(H2O)} n , 1, was 72% (0.039 g). Elemental analysis calculated for (C26H34Cd2I2N8O9) n  (1): C, 28.88; H, 3.17; N, 10.36, Found: C, 28.82; H,3.11; N, 10.26%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1663, νas(COO-); 1380, νs(COO-). For electrospray ionization (ESI † ) data, see Figure S1.

elements.content: Crystal data and experimental details for data collection and structure refinement are reported in Table S1. The crystal structure of 1 was determined by X-ray diffraction methods. A suitable single crystal of 1 having an appropriate dimension (0.412 × 0.085 × 0.012 mm) was used for data collection via Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ, 0.710 73 Å). The unit cell parameters and crystal-orientation matrices were determined by least-squares refinement of all reflections within hkl ranges of −22 < h < 21, −21 < k < 21, −20 < l < 19. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Data were collected applying the condition I > 2σ­(I). The collected data were integrated using SAINT program, and the absorption correction was made with SADABS. Full matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were performed using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. All calculations were performed using SHELXL 97, SHELXS 97, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 program.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Crystal data and experimental details for data collection and structure refinement are reported in Table S1. The crystal structure of 1 was determined by X-ray diffraction methods. A suitable single crystal of 1 having an appropriate dimension (0.412 × 0.085 × 0.012 mm) was used for data collection via Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ, 0.71073 Å). The unit cell parameters and crystal-orientation matrices were determined by least-squares refinement of all reflections within hkl ranges of -22 < h < 21, -21 < k < 21, -20 < l < 19. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Data were collected applying the condition I > 2σ(I). The collected data were integrated using SAINT program, and the absorption correction was made with SADABS. Full matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were performed using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. All calculations were performed using SHELXL 97, SHELXS 97, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 program.

elements.content: Gaussian-09 program package was used to generate optimized geometries and molecular functions of 1. Hybrid DFT-B3LYP functional was used all over the calculations. For C, H, and N the LanL2DZ basis set was assigned, and on this basis set the comparable pseudopotential was used for Cd without any symmetry constraint. The vibrational frequency computation was also executed for 1′ (without solvent molecule) and I 2 @1′ (after iodine sorption of 1′) to ensure that the optimized geometries signify the local minima and that there are only positive eigenvalues. The single-crystal X-ray coordinates were used in the calculation. To assign the low-lying electronic transitions in the experimental spectra, TD-DFT calculations of both 1′ and I 2 @1′ were done. We computed the lowest 80 singlet–singlet transitions in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) using the conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM). Gauss Sum was used to calculate the fractional contributions of various groups to each molecular orbital.
elements.clean_text:
DFT and TD DFT Calculations

Gaussian-09 program package was used to generate optimized geometries and molecular functions of 1. Hybrid DFT-B3LYP functional was used all over the calculations. For C, H, and N the LanL2DZ basis set was assigned, and on this basis set the comparable pseudopotential was used for Cd without any symmetry constraint. The vibrational frequency computation was also executed for 1' (without solvent molecule) and I  2  @1' (after iodine sorption of 1') to ensure that the optimized geometries signify the local minima and that there are only positive eigenvalues. The single-crystal X-ray coordinates were used in the calculation. To assign the low-lying electronic transitions in the experimental spectra, TD-DFT calculations of both 1' and I  2  @1' were done. We computed the lowest 80 singlet-singlet transitions in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) using the conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM). Gauss Sum was used to calculate the fractional contributions of various groups to each molecular orbital.

elements.content: The compound 1 was pretreated with dry methanol, for every 6 h; the fresh solvent was exchanged, and the process was continued for 2 d. Then, it was degassed at 120 °C for 4 h, where the sample is activated due to generating the porosity. After desolvation of 1, the porosity of the activated compound 1′ was analyzed by BET surface area analyses. Gas adsorption measurements were done volumetrically using activated 1′. The surface area analysis of 1′ was performed by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and was recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). We carried forward iodine sorption kinetics in cyclohexane medium, and iodine desorption or releasing experiments were done in ethanol medium with the help of PerkinElmer Lambda 25 UV–vis spectrophotometer in a 1 × 1 cm quartz optical cell maintained at 25 °C.
elements.clean_text:
N2 and I2 Sorption Studies

The compound 1 was pretreated with dry methanol, for every 6 h; the fresh solvent was exchanged, and the process was continued for 2 d. Then, it was degassed at 120 °C for 4 h, where the sample is activated due to generating the porosity. After desolvation of 1, the porosity of the activated compound 1' was analyzed by BET surface area analyses. Gas adsorption measurements were done volumetrically using activated 1'. The surface area analysis of 1' was performed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and was recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). We carried forward iodine sorption kinetics in cyclohexane medium, and iodine desorption or releasing experiments were done in ethanol medium with the help of PerkinElmer Lambda 25 UV-vis spectrophotometer in a 1 × 1 cm quartz optical cell maintained at 25 °C.

elements.content: The optical characterization of all the synthesized compounds was performed with the help of Shimadzu 2401 PC UV–vis spectrophotometer, in the range of 200–900 nm. The dielectrical study was performed by evaluating capacitance (C), impedance (Z), and phase angle (θ) of the sample as a function of frequency (40 Hz–11 MHz) using a computer-controlled Agilent make precision 4294A LCR meter. The electrical characterization was performed with the help of Keithley 2400 source meter, interfaced with personal computer (PC).
elements.clean_text:
Electrical Conductivity Study

The optical characterization of all the synthesized compounds was performed with the help of Shimadzu 2401 PC UV-vis spectrophotometer, in the range of 200-900 nm. The dielectrical study was performed by evaluating capacitance (C), impedance (Z), and phase angle (θ) of the sample as a function of frequency (40 Hz-11 MHz) using a computer-controlled Agilent make precision 4294A LCR meter. The electrical characterization was performed with the help of Keithley 2400 source meter, interfaced with personal computer (PC).

elements.content: When methanol solution of INH buffered with DMF was layered on the aqueous solution of CdI2 followed by the addition of H2BDC, isolated was {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1, and the structure was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) studies. The octahedral unit of coordination polymer is shown in a. The compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4. The asymmetric unit contains distorted octahedral Cd­(II) center bonded to two INH ligands, one BDC–2 linker, and one iodine (a). The distortion octahedral geometry arises via O,N chelation of one INH; monodentate pyridyl–N coordination with the second INH; O,O chelation of BDC2–; thus, CdIN2O3 coordination arrangement (a) is achieved to construct 2D layer (b). The architecture is constructed via three-connected uninodal hcb topology layer, with the point symbol or Schläfli symbol {63} (), and the extended point symbol is [6.6.6]. Interlayer hydrogen bonding (a) with DMF and H2O in 1 along the bc plane makes the architecture robust and stable. Then further two 2D layers are further aggregated to construct the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure in 2D+2D polycatenated fashion (Figure S2) via face-to-face interlayer π–π stacking interactions (b) between two different INH pyridine rings. The π–π distance from the centroid to centroid is ∼3.575 (3) Å (), and the interlayer hydrogen bonding between INH in a first layer to oxygen of coordinated DMF of neighboring layer, H­(4A)···O(2) is 2.062 Å and H­(3A)···O(2) is 2.067 Å. The hydrogen-bonding interaction such as H3C···O5 2.907(2) Å improves the interlayer strength (Table S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure

When methanol solution of INH buffered with DMF was layered on the aqueous solution of CdI2 followed by the addition of H2BDC, isolated was {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]⋅(2DMF)(H2O)} n , 1, and the structure was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) studies. The octahedral unit of coordination polymer is shown in a. The compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4. The asymmetric unit contains distorted octahedral Cd(II) center bonded to two INH ligands, one BDC-2 linker, and one iodine (a). The distortion octahedral geometry arises via O,N chelation of one INH; monodentate pyridyl-N coordination with the second INH; O,O chelation of BDC2-; thus, CdIN2O3 coordination arrangement (a) is achieved to construct 2D layer (b). The architecture is constructed via three-connected uninodal hcb topology layer, with the point symbol or Schläfli symbol {63} (), and the extended point symbol is [6.6.6]. Interlayer hydrogen bonding (a) with DMF and H2O in 1 along the bc plane makes the architecture robust and stable. Then further two 2D layers are further aggregated to construct the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure in 2D+2D polycatenated fashion (Figure S2) via face-to-face interlayer π-π stacking interactions (b) between two different INH pyridine rings. The π-π distance from the centroid to centroid is ~3.575 (3) Å (), and the interlayer hydrogen bonding between INH in a first layer to oxygen of coordinated DMF of neighboring layer, H(4A)⋅⋅⋅O(2) is 2.062 Å and H(3A)⋅⋅⋅O(2) is 2.067 Å. The hydrogen-bonding interaction such as H3C⋅⋅⋅O5 2.907(2) Å improves the interlayer strength (Table S2).

elements.content: In this study, the optical spectra of 1′ and I 2 @1′ (inset, a,b) were recorded from the deposited thin films in the range of 250–450 nm. The UV–vis spectrum of 1′ depicts strong absorption in the visible region at ∼340 nm, whereas I 2 @1′ absorbs at ∼360 nm. The TD-DFT calculations (with the singlet spin state) in DMSO using the CPCM model was tried to explain the origin of the UV–vis transition of 1′ and I 2 @1′. The calculated energies of selected transitions with oscillation strengths (f) and molecular orbitals (MOs) are listed in Table S3. The λcalc value for 1′ is 342.2 nm (LIodide → LINH), and that of I 2 @1′ main band appears at 338.8 nm with a shoulder at 358.5 nm (LINH → LIodide); these are referred to as the inter ligand charge transfer transitions (ILCT; ).
elements.clean_text:
Spectral Characterization

Optical Characterization

In this study, the optical spectra of 1' and I  2  @1' (inset, a,b) were recorded from the deposited thin films in the range of 250-450 nm. The UV-vis spectrum of 1' depicts strong absorption in the visible region at ~340 nm, whereas I  2  @1' absorbs at ~360 nm. The TD-DFT calculations (with the singlet spin state) in DMSO using the CPCM model was tried to explain the origin of the UV-vis transition of 1' and I  2  @1'. The calculated energies of selected transitions with oscillation strengths (f) and molecular orbitals (MOs) are listed in Table S3. The λcalc value for 1' is 342.2 nm (LIodide → LINH), and that of I  2  @1' main band appears at 338.8 nm with a shoulder at 358.5 nm (LINH → LIodide); these are referred to as the inter ligand charge transfer transitions (ILCT; ).

elements.content: The optical band gap of the as-synthesized compounds was estimated using Tauc equation () αh ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n where α is the absorption coefficient, E g is the band gap, h is Planck’s constant, ν is the frequency of light, and the exponent n is the electron transition processes-dependent constant. A is a constant, which is considered as 1 for the ideal case. Here the value of the exponent n in the above equation was considered as n = 0.5. The plot of (αhν)2 versus h ν of the synthesized compounds is demonstrated in . By extrapolating the linear region of the plot (αhν)2 versus h ν to α = 0 absorption, the values of the direct optical band gap (E g) of the synthesized compounds 1′ and I 2 @1′ were evaluated as 3.7 and 3.5 eV, respectively, whereas DFT-computed band gaps are 3.48 and 3.19 eV (I 2 @1′; ). From the DFT calculation (), we assumed that the Cd–I···I–I interaction in I 2 @1′ may be the reason for the band gap decrement with respect to 1′, which supports the experiment.

elements.content: For surface area analysis of activated compound 1′, gas adsorption measurement was performed. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm () was recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). A type IV adsorption–desorption isotherm is observed with a very large H2-type hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (p/p 0) range from 0.45 to 0.99. At the low relative pressure, typically at p/p 0 < 0.1, the micropores are starting to fill through monolayer adsorption reflecting a steep uptake of N2 in the onset of adsorption isotherm. With increasing relative pressure (p/p 0 > 0.1) N2 filling may continue on the multilayer phase to a critical film thickness corresponding to relative pressure at p/p 0 = 0.7. Further increase in p/p 0 upsurge in N2 adsorption is observed, which may be due to capillary condensation, indicating the generation of mesoporosity. When the p/p 0 is ∼1.0, saturation point is reached; the internal pore structure of the material fills with condensed (liquid) nitrogen. In the desorption isotherm, pore evaporation starts at relative pressure 0.5 and continues to 0.45; further decrease in p/p 0 does not show significant desorption. This feature may be H2-type hysteresis, demonstrating disordered pores or pore blocking. The observed hysteresis might be due to multiple reasons: changes in the volume of adsorbent, irreversible uptake of molecules in the pores, or swelling of nonrigid pores. The typical pattern of the isotherm has suggested the existence of a cagelike formation of large uniform mesopores connected by windows of the small aperture. Furthermore, the initial adsorption pattern clearly indicates the presence of microporosity in the compound. From the single-crystal structure data, it is also evident that the 1 is microporous in nature.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Studies

Gas Adsorption of 1': Micropore to Mesopore Switching

For surface area analysis of activated compound 1', gas adsorption measurement was performed. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm () was recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K). A type IV adsorption-desorption isotherm is observed with a very large H2-type hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (p/p 0) range from 0.45 to 0.99. At the low relative pressure, typically at p/p 0 < 0.1, the micropores are starting to fill through monolayer adsorption reflecting a steep uptake of N2 in the onset of adsorption isotherm. With increasing relative pressure (p/p 0 > 0.1) N2 filling may continue on the multilayer phase to a critical film thickness corresponding to relative pressure at p/p 0 = 0.7. Further increase in p/p 0 upsurge in N2 adsorption is observed, which may be due to capillary condensation, indicating the generation of mesoporosity. When the p/p 0 is ~1.0, saturation point is reached; the internal pore structure of the material fills with condensed (liquid) nitrogen. In the desorption isotherm, pore evaporation starts at relative pressure 0.5 and continues to 0.45; further decrease in p/p 0 does not show significant desorption. This feature may be H2-type hysteresis, demonstrating disordered pores or pore blocking. The observed hysteresis might be due to multiple reasons: changes in the volume of adsorbent, irreversible uptake of molecules in the pores, or swelling of nonrigid pores. The typical pattern of the isotherm has suggested the existence of a cagelike formation of large uniform mesopores connected by windows of the small aperture. Furthermore, the initial adsorption pattern clearly indicates the presence of microporosity in the compound. From the single-crystal structure data, it is also evident that the 1 is microporous in nature.

elements.content: The p/p 0 position of the inflection point of the isotherm was evidently related to diameter, which was found to be typically in the mesopore range (2–50 nm), and the sharpness of the steps indicated the distribution of uniform mesopores, which was further confirmed by the pore size distribution plot using Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method as shown in Figure S3. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of the sample were 611 and 846 m2 g–1, respectively, with an average pore diameter of 14.7 nm and pore volume of 0.26 cm3 g–1, which is typical of microporous pore volume. Thus, gas adsorption studies clearly indicate the microporous and mesoporous features of 1′. The nature of mesoporosity having a pore diameter of 14.7 nm presumably originates from the interparticle voids, since the unit cell parameters are typically within the range of 2 nm, interpenetration in the framework structure presumably being the reason for the narrow aperture of the window. The high specific surface area with microporous and mesoporous features thus have prompted us to perform iodine (diameter being 4.94 Å) uptake study with 1′ in cyclohexane medium.

elements.content: Activated compound 1′ showed reversible I2 uptake and release. After an excess amount of I2 was loaded by 1′ in cyclohexane medium the color of the crystals gradually changed from colorless to dark brown, and I 2 @1′ was isolated. The PXRD analysis of as-synthesized 1 exactly matches with that simulated from single-crystal data, which indicates the phase purity of the bulk. The PXRD of 1′ and iodine-loaded compound I 2 @1′ shows slightly changed (Figure S4) pattern and supports the uptake of iodine molecule in the cavity of 1′. The examination of thermal stability (TGA) of 1′ and I 2 @1′ revealed the higher stability of 1′ (up to 320 °C), while I 2 @1′ is relatively less stable, and thermal loss starts at 150 °C. The compound 1 is least stable of these three, and solvent (H2O) begins to release at 70 °C; the second step loses solvent (DMF) at 170 °C (Figure S5). The uptake and removal of iodine were investigated by UV–vis spectroscopy (, S6, and S7). The I2 sorption kinetics was systematically analyzed with the MIL-53 series by examining the effect of the functionalization of organic linkers by introducing nine different functional groups such as −H, −CH3, −NH2, −OH, −COOH, −NO2, −Cl, and −Br. The excellent porosity in the activated compound 1′ and the presence of Cd–I in each hexagonal vertex position influences the charge transfer mechanism through iodine bridging {Cd–I···(I–I) x } n .
elements.clean_text:
Uptake and Release of Iodine

Activated compound 1' showed reversible I2 uptake and release. After an excess amount of I2 was loaded by 1' in cyclohexane medium the color of the crystals gradually changed from colorless to dark brown, and I  2  @1' was isolated. The PXRD analysis of as-synthesized 1 exactly matches with that simulated from single-crystal data, which indicates the phase purity of the bulk. The PXRD of 1' and iodine-loaded compound I  2  @1' shows slightly changed (Figure S4) pattern and supports the uptake of iodine molecule in the cavity of 1'. The examination of thermal stability (TGA) of 1' and I  2  @1' revealed the higher stability of 1' (up to 320 °C), while I  2  @1' is relatively less stable, and thermal loss starts at 150 °C. The compound 1 is least stable of these three, and solvent (H2O) begins to release at 70 °C; the second step loses solvent (DMF) at 170 °C (Figure S5). The uptake and removal of iodine were investigated by UV-vis spectroscopy (, S6, and S7). The I2 sorption kinetics was systematically analyzed with the MIL-53 series by examining the effect of the functionalization of organic linkers by introducing nine different functional groups such as -H, -CH3, -NH2, -OH, -COOH, -NO2, -Cl, and -Br. The excellent porosity in the activated compound 1' and the presence of Cd-I in each hexagonal vertex position influences the charge transfer mechanism through iodine bridging {Cd-I⋅⋅⋅(I-I) x } n .

elements.clean_text: 9  Sorption kinetics of iodine monitored via UV-vis spectroscopy in cyclohexane solvent.

elements.content: The activated compound, 1′, was placed in a preweighed vial, and 52 mg of 1′ was soaked in a covered lid vial with 3 mL of a cyclohexane (3 mL)/I2 (∼0.01 mol L–1) solution at room temperature (no stirring). The consequential dispersion settles in less than 5 min, and UV–vis spectroscopy was used to characterize the supernatant and determine the iodine concentration (). Typically, the sorption ability of 1′ was very quick, and no further change was observed after 70 h, which indicates that the system had reached equilibrium. The color of the crystals was intensified from colorless through yellow and dark brown to black with time ().

The consequential dispersion settles in less than 5 min, and UV-vis spectroscopy was used to characterize the supernatant and determine the iodine concentration (). Typically, the sorption ability of 1' was very quick, and no further change was observed after 70 h, which indicates that the system had reached equilibrium. The color of the crystals was intensified from colorless through yellow and dark brown to black with time ().

elements.content: The sorption kinetics of I2 monitored using UV–vis spectroscopy shows that the gradual decrease of iodine concentration from the solution. Time-variable iodine uptake of 1′ in cyclohexane was observed by naked eye (Figure S7). The sorption efficiency 98.9% of 1′ is achieved within 70 h (Figure S6b), which has surpassed that of reported MIL-53-NH2 (60%). The plot of log­(q e – q t) versus time (min) during I2 uptake by 1′ follows pseudo-first-order reaction, and the rate constant (k) is 0.1246 min–1 (Table S4). Iodine uptake is calculated by thermal analysis and shows 40 wt % loss after 200 °C, which corresponds to three molecules of iodine per unit cell of 1′ (Figure S5). By the gravimetric analysis, the preweighted 52 mg of 1′ was increased to 73 mg, where 40.38% weight has been increased after loading of iodine and also supports the thermal data. Weak SXRD data could not help to establish the structure of loaded I2 sample I 2 @1′. But most of the peak positions in the PXRD analysis of I 2 @1′ are similar to that of 1′, indicating that the host framework is preserved, but intensity and width of the peaks are shifted (Figure S4). The Raman spectrum of I 2 @1′ confirms the sorption of iodine within the PCP surface, which is depicted in Figure S8. In the Raman spectra, the characteristic peaks that appear at 170–172 cm–1 refer to adsorbed I2 in the cavity of PCP, and simultaneously the another peak at ∼112 cm–1 indicates the capture of I2 via Cd–I···I–I fashion in the core of PCP. To support the iodine adsorption behavior we performed FESEM mapping and EDS spectrum of compound 1′ (before I2 load) and I 2 @1′ (after I2 load) for the elemental analyses, which were clearly summarized in and S10 and evidently sustained that compound 1′ successfully adsorbed iodine in it. In Table S6 elemental analysis data illustrated that the amount of iodine increased after I2 loading took place.

elements.content: Desorption of iodine from I 2 @1′ was performed by immersing the compound in fresh ethanol; the color of the crystal is changed gradually from black to yellow, to off-white, along with deepening of ethanol solution (b). Further immersion of colorless crystal obtained from the previous experiment to I2 solution in cyclohexane restores its color, indicating that 1′ is recyclable in the practical application of I2 capture, and thus reversibility of I2 sorption/desorption is proved. UV–Vis spectra were obtained to further investigate the delivery of I2 from I 2 @1′ with time to ethanol medium (Figure S9).

elements.content: The optical band gap (1′, 3.7 eV; I 2 @1′, 3.5 eV) lies within the semiconductor limit, and the presence of strong absorption in the visible wavelength signifies some conducting nature of the compounds. Motivated from this result, the electrical conductivity of the compounds is checked in terms of dielectric study. In this regard, we used the impedance spectroscopy method. This study has been widely used to investigate the charge transport behavior, which provides a correlation between the electrical and structural properties of a material.
elements.clean_text:
Electrical Characterization

Dielectric Measurements

The optical band gap (1', 3.7 eV; I  2  @1', 3.5 eV) lies within the semiconductor limit, and the presence of strong absorption in the visible wavelength signifies some conducting nature of the compounds. Motivated from this result, the electrical conductivity of the compounds is checked in terms of dielectric study. In this regard, we used the impedance spectroscopy method. This study has been widely used to investigate the charge transport behavior, which provides a correlation between the electrical and structural properties of a material.

elements.content: The Nyquist plot (a) shows the measured electrical impedance of the compounds at room temperature. The impedance plot comprises a single prominent semicircular arc in the high-frequency region, which means that the grain boundaries were not experimentally recorded in the impedance data. The presence of single semicircular arcs is attributed to the bulk properties of the material, and it arises due to the parallel combination of the bulk resistance (R b) and bulk capacitance (C b), (a). These semicircles at the high-frequency region are related to the electrode resistance and also reflect the charge transfer resistance at the electrode/composite interface. The radius of the semicircle depicts the bulk resistance R b (direct-current (dc) resistance) of the sample. The intercept of the semicircular arc on the real axis (Z″) gives the bulk resistance R b (dc resistance). The lower radius of arc corresponding to bulk resistance of I 2 @1′ is much smaller than that of 1′, which depicts that the I 2 @1′ possesses less bulk resistance. Data (Table S5) show the higher charge transfer resistance 18.43 KΩ of 1′ than that of 5.31 KΩ of I 2 @1′. It explains the better conductivity of I 2 @1′ (2.66 × 10–5 S m–1) and facilitates better interfacial charge transfer rather than that of 1′ (7.67 × 10–6 S m–1).

elements.content: Alternating-current (AC) conductivity measurements show that the increase in frequency at lower frequency range (<6 × 106 Hz) does not show any improvement of conductivity, while improvement in the conductance is noted within the frequency of 9 × 106 to 1 × 107 Hz (a). This explains that the interior of the semiconductor is a region of relatively low conductivity, even when the conduction process is electrode-limited, and electron needs significant energy to release exciton for crossing the Fermi energy level. In general, the conductivity increases with the increase in frequency when it depends on free carriers.

elements.content: The relative dielectric constant of the compounds was measured from capacitance versus frequency plot (b). It is observed that the capacitance (C) varies with frequency (f) at constant bias potential. The room-temperature capacitance of both the compounds (1′ and I 2 @1′) is shown to be frequency-dependent at relatively low frequencies (up to ∼1 × 102 Hz). The capacitance decreases with increasing frequency and becomes saturated at higher frequency. From the saturation level, the relative permittivity of the compounds was calculated employing ε r = 1 ε 0 × C × d A where ε0 is the permittivity of free space, ε r is the relative permittivity of the synthesized material, C is the capacitance (at saturation), and d and A are the thickness and effective area of the pellet, respectively. With the above formula, the relative electric constant (εr) of the materials was estimated and given in Table S3.

With the above formula, the relative electric constant (εr) of the materials was estimated and given in Table S3.

elements.content: All these parameters pointed out that I 2 @1′ is a better contender in the view of electrical conductivity than 1′. Motivated from these results, we designed Schottky devices of the newly synthesized compound to check further the applicability in active electronic devices. Hence, we calculated the Schottky parameters and studied the electrical behavior.

elements.content: The impedance analysis prompted us to measure the inherent electrical properties of 1′ and I 2 @1′ and also to fabricate device structures due to their easy solution processability. To analyze the electrical properties, current–voltage (I–V) measurements of 1′ and I 2 @1′-based multiple devices were recorded under dark and light irradiation (AM 1.5G) conditions at the corresponding applied bias voltage sequentially within the limit ±2 V. The I–V characteristic curves () of the newly fabricated devices exhibit undoubtedly a highly nonlinear rectifying behavior. The nonlinearity of the I–V curve indicates that the prevalent conduction mechanism is nonohmic and rectifying in nature, similar to the Schottky diode behavior. The rectification ratios (I on /I off) of compound 1′-based devices were found to be 22.59 (dark) and 32.55 (light), whereas, for I 2 @1′-based devices, it was estimated as 25.33 (dark) and 45.33 (light). The photosensitivity for compounds 1′ and I 2 @1′-based devices was measured as 1.64 and 1.97, respectively. The conductivities of 1′ on the devices was measured as 5.14 × 10–4 Sm–1 (dark) and 8.11 × 10–4 Sm–1 (light) and for I 2 @1′ as 6.34 × 10–4 Sm–1 (dark) and 1.21 × 10–3 Sm–1 (light). The measured conductivity of both the materials falls well in the semiconductor region. The conductivity of the devices constituted by 1′ and I 2 @1′ are quite impressive on comparing with published information. The conductivity of present material increases after soaking illumination of incident radiation. For 1′, the enhancement of conductivity is ∼1.5 times, whereas after iodine sorption that compound (I 2 @1′) shows an enhancement of ∼2 times. This implies that the I 2 @1′ shows enhanced electrical conductivity, which may be attributed to the role of captured I2 in the electron transportation process. The host–guest interaction between the compound and I2 may augment the polar effect and hence the enhancement of electrical conductivity of the composite I 2 @1′. It is well-known that metal-bound iodine M-I is electron-deficient with respect to free iodine, I2; thus, halogen halide interaction may assist to form polyiodides, in which iodide serves as an electron acceptor, and iodine is the electron donor. The formation of polyhalide may explain the Grotthuss-like charge transfer mechanism of I– + I2 → [I···I–I]− ↔ [I–I···I]− → I2 + I– or I3– + I2 → [I–I–I···I–I]− ↔ [I–I···I–I–I]− → I2 + I3 – for electron conductivity. For assured electronic interaction between I–, I3 –, and I2 without long diffusion lengths, the presence of multiple polyiodide units formed in the material, that is, [I–···I2···I–] n and [I–···I2] n , may be the possible reason for unusual charge transportation and for holding back the further enhancement of electrical conductivity. Therefore, the charge transport in the material disfavors an ideal electron hopping mechanism as expected to achieve considerably high conductivity.

Photosensitivity Study

The impedance analysis prompted us to measure the inherent electrical properties of 1' and I  2  @1' and also to fabricate device structures due to their easy solution processability. To analyze the electrical properties, current-voltage (I-V) measurements of 1' and I  2  @1'-based multiple devices were recorded under dark and light irradiation (AM 1.5G) conditions at the corresponding applied bias voltage sequentially within the limit ±2 V. The I-V characteristic curves () of the newly fabricated devices exhibit undoubtedly a highly nonlinear rectifying behavior. The nonlinearity of the I-V curve indicates that the prevalent conduction mechanism is nonohmic and rectifying in nature, similar to the Schottky diode behavior. The rectification ratios (I on /I off) of compound 1'-based devices were found to be 22.59 (dark) and 32.55 (light), whereas, for I  2  @1'-based devices, it was estimated as 25.33 (dark) and 45.33 (light). The photosensitivity for compounds 1' and I  2  @1'-based devices was measured as 1.64 and 1.97, respectively. The conductivities of 1' on the devices was measured as 5.14 × 10-4 Sm-1 (dark) and 8.11 × 10-4 Sm-1 (light) and for I  2  @1' as 6.34 × 10-4 Sm-1 (dark) and 1.21 × 10-3 Sm-1 (light). The measured conductivity of both the materials falls well in the semiconductor region. The conductivity of the devices constituted by 1' and I  2  @1' are quite impressive on comparing with published information. The conductivity of present material increases after soaking illumination of incident radiation. For 1', the enhancement of conductivity is ~1.5 times, whereas after iodine sorption that compound (I  2  @1') shows an enhancement of ~2 times. This implies that the I  2  @1' shows enhanced electrical conductivity, which may be attributed to the role of captured I2 in the electron transportation process. The host-guest interaction between the compound and I2 may augment the polar effect and hence the enhancement of electrical conductivity of the composite I  2  @1'. It is well-known that metal-bound iodine M-I is electron-deficient with respect to free iodine, I2; thus, halogen halide interaction may assist to form polyiodides, in which iodide serves as an electron acceptor, and iodine is the electron donor. The formation of polyhalide may explain the Grotthuss-like charge transfer mechanism of I- + I2 → [I⋅⋅⋅I-I]- ↔ [I-I⋅⋅⋅I]- → I2 + I- or I3- + I2 → [I-I-I⋅⋅⋅I-I]- ↔ [I-I⋅⋅⋅I-I-I]- → I2 + I3 - for electron conductivity. For assured electronic interaction between I-, I3 -, and I2 without long diffusion lengths, the presence of multiple polyiodide units formed in the material, that is, [I-⋅⋅⋅I2⋅⋅⋅I-] n  and [I-⋅⋅⋅I2] n , may be the possible reason for unusual charge transportation and for holding back the further enhancement of electrical conductivity. Therefore, the charge transport in the material disfavors an ideal electron hopping mechanism as expected to achieve considerably high conductivity.

elements.content: The ideality factor (η) and series resistance (R S) are calculated from the y-intercept and the slope of dV/d­(ln I ) versus I (a) graph, respectively. It is noted that the metal semiconductor (MS) junction of the devices is not exactly ideal and lies with η of 3.77 and 3.11 in dark and photo conditions, respectively. This deviation from ideal value (η = 1) indicates the existence of inhomogeneities of the Schottky barrier height and also signifies the presence of interface states and series resistance. However, the important observation is that the value of ideality factor (η) of both the compounds approached more ideal after light soaking, which is generally an indication of less interfacial charge recombination and better homogeneity of Schottky junctions, that is, it may be stated that these compounds possess less carrier recombination at the junction, that is, better barrier homogeneity under photo-irradiation condition. A plot of H(I) versus I will also lead to a straight line (b) with the y-axis intercept being equal to ηφB. Using just obtained ideality factor (η) value, we calculated the value of barrier height (φB). The measured barrier height, ideality factor, and series resistance under the dark condition for the metal (Al)–semiconductor (synthesized compounds) junctions are listed in . From the data, it can be seen that the series resistance (R S) values from two different methods using Cheung’s functions are in concurrence with each other. Series resistance (R S) in both cases decreases after soaking light. These results indicate a certain reduction in carrier density in the depletion region of the rectifier through the introduction of traps and recombination centers associated with illumination effect. These good agreements of the determined values give the evidence for the validity of these methods for the determination of the series resistance of the Schottky diode.

elements.content:
We also estimated some key parameters like transit time (τ), diffusion coefficient (D), and diffusion length of charge carrier (L D) of the materials to analyze charge transport across the junction.

When a metal–semiconductor junction is formed, the diffusion length (L D) of charge carriers plays an influential role in device performance. With the estimated values of all the parameters in a using the power law (I ∝ V m , where m is the value of slope) the governing mechanism of carrier conduction can be concluded. The value of m greater or equal to 2 (m ≥ 2) indicates space-charge–limited-current (SCLC) mechanism, whereas being less than or equal to 1 (m ≤ 1) signify Ohmic character. Data (a) reveal that there were two distinguishable slopes with different values, which were marked as region-I and region-II. In the region-I, when the slope is ∼1, current follows the relation I ∝ V, which refers to the Ohmic regime. In the region-II, the slope is ∼2, where current is proportional to V 2 (a). This is very characteristic of a trap-free SCLC regime. If the injected carriers are more than the background carriers, the injected carriers spread and create a space charge field. The SCLC theory, which has recently drawn popular attention, was adopted here to estimate the mobility of materials.

elements.content: SCLC region is demonstrated in . The higher mobility implied higher transport rate under irradiation, while the number of charge carriers also increased under the light. The increased diffusion length under illumination revealed that the charge carriers must travel more length before being recombined, which led to the eventual increase in current displayed by the devices under the light. From these obtained values, it can be clearly stated that the charge transport properties of our synthesized materials improved after light soaking ().

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized and characterized an isoniazid bridged, 2D+2D, the hcb-type parallel polycatenetrated structure of Cd­(II)-based PCP. Single-crystal structure clearly showed the porous framework in the PCP, which was further confirmed with nitrogen adsorption analysis. The solvent-exchanged activated PCP sample (1′) showed a high specific BET surface area with pore size typically in the mesopore range. The inconsistency in the pore diameter observed from single-crystal XRD data and nitrogen adsorption–desorption analysis is presumably because of an interparticle void that forms mesopore structure, whereas unit cell parameters of the structure typically in the range of 2 nm only form microporous architecture. The pore architecture along with pore size and having Cd–I bond as an active site in the porous channel of the PCP was suitable for strong sorption of iodine to form charge transfer complex reversibly. The iodine sorption–desorption kinetics were regulated through the change of polarity of the solvent, which was clearly visible by color change. The iodine-sorbed compound I 2 @1′ showed ∼1.5 times higher electrical conductivity and enhanced photosensitivity than the pristine activated PCP, 1′.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized and characterized an isoniazid bridged, 2D+2D, the hcb-type parallel polycatenetrated structure of Cd(II)-based PCP. Single-crystal structure clearly showed the porous framework in the PCP, which was further confirmed with nitrogen adsorption analysis. The solvent-exchanged activated PCP sample (1') showed a high specific BET surface area with pore size typically in the mesopore range. The inconsistency in the pore diameter observed from single-crystal XRD data and nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis is presumably because of an interparticle void that forms mesopore structure, whereas unit cell parameters of the structure typically in the range of 2 nm only form microporous architecture. The pore architecture along with pore size and having Cd-I bond as an active site in the porous channel of the PCP was suitable for strong sorption of iodine to form charge transfer complex reversibly. The iodine sorption-desorption kinetics were regulated through the change of polarity of the solvent, which was clearly visible by color change. The iodine-sorbed compound I  2  @1' showed ~1.5 times higher electrical conductivity and enhanced photosensitivity than the pristine activated PCP, 1'.

cln_elements.content:
To a methanol solution (10 mL) of INH (0.137 g, 1 mmol) was carefully layered by the help of DMF solvent the aqueous solution of (10 mL) of CdI2 (0.366 g, 1 mmol). H2BDC (0.166 g, 1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) was neutralized with Et3N solution (0.212 g, 2 mmol) and was injected cautiously over the isoniazid solution followed by DMF solvent to make an undisturbed layer. It was then allowed to diffuse for one week. The colorless needle-shaped crystals were deposited on the glass wall. The crystals were separated mechanically under a microscope, washed with a methanol and water (1:1) mixture, and dried. The yield of {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1, was 72% (0.039 g). Elemental analysis calculated for (C26H34Cd2I2N8O9) n (1): C, 28.88; H, 3.17; N, 10.36, Found: C, 28.82; H,3.11; N, 10.26%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1663, νas(COO−); 1380, νs(COO−). For electrospray ionization (ESI † ) data, see Figure S1.

The activated compound, 1′, was placed in a preweighed vial, and 52 mg of 1′ was soaked in a covered lid vial with 3 mL of a cyclohexane (3 mL)/I2 (∼0.01 mol L–1) solution at room temperature (no stirring). The consequential dispersion settles in less than 5 min, and UV–vis spectroscopy was used to characterize the supernatant and determine the iodine concentration (). Typically, the sorption ability of 1′ was very quick, and no further change was observed after 70 h, which indicates that the system had reached equilibrium. The color of the crystals was intensified from colorless through yellow and dark brown to black with time ().

The crystals were separated mechanically under a microscope, washed with a methanol and water (1:1) mixture, and dried. The yield of {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]⋅(2DMF)(H2O)} n , 1, was 72% (0.039 g). Elemental analysis calculated for (C26H34Cd2I2N8O9) n  (1): C, 28.88; H, 3.17; N, 10.36, Found: C, 28.82; H,3.11; N, 10.26%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1663, νas(COO-); 1380, νs(COO-). For electrospray ionization (ESI † ) data, see Figure S1.

The activated compound, 1', was placed in a preweighed vial, and 52 mg of 1' was soaked in a covered lid vial with 3 mL of a cyclohexane (3 mL)/I2 (~0.01 mol L-1) solution at room temperature (no stirring). cln_elements.content:
The porous materials are efficient storage and exchange systems of small molecules and ions. Some of the porous materials may be used as an efficient storage system of iodine. Herein, a honeycomb (hcb)-type 2D+2D (2D = two-dimensional), parallel polycatenated Porous Polycatenated Coordination Polymer (PPCP) {[Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2]·(2DMF)­(H2O)} n , 1 (INH, isoniazid; H2BDC, terephthalic acid; DMF, dimethylformamide) is characterized that reversibly uptakes I2 from organic medium (more than 98%). The single-crystal X-ray structure determination reveals the CdIN2O3 distorted octahedral geometry, and the microporous channel (∼1.7 nm) is generated by polycatenation along with the supramolecular interaction. On thermal treatment at 120 °C the polymer, 1, loses solvents, while the crystalinity is reserved. The solvent-free activated state of the coordination polymer, [Cd2I2(BDC)2(INH)2] n , 1′, adsorbs N2, and the adsorption–desorption analysis displayed the increase in porosity to mesoporous range (∼14.7 nm) with very high specific Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area, which may be due to the rise in interparticle void space. Iodine (I2) sorption studies of mesoporous architecture of 1′ show high I2 removal efficiency (98.9%), which is revealed from the reversible iodine uptake kinetics study. Typically, uptake of three moles of I2 per unit cell associated with color change from colorless to brown is discernible from thermal analysis. Interestingly, the iodine-loaded polymer (I 2 @1′) shows ∼1.5 times enhancement in electrical conductivity compared to 1′ only. The optical band gap obtained from density functional theory (DFT) calculation and the experimental values are 1, 3.48 eV (DFT), 3.70 eV (experimental) and I 2 @1′, 3.19 eV (DFT), 3.50 eV (experimental). The lowering of band gap after I2 sorption is presumably due to the interaction of I2 with Cd–I (Cd–I···I–I) in hcb core, which was evidenced from Raman spectra analysis.

The 3D aggregate via packing mode 2 × 2 × 2 clearly shows the porosity of the coordination polymer along the ab plane (17.2 × 8.31 Å2), where DMF and water are encapsulated a. The pores, with the sizes of 17.2 × 8.31 Å2 (b measured by the C7/C7 and O5/O5 distances), are filled with lattice H2O and DMF molecule and show ∼11.5% solvent-accessible volumes (a). With removal of solvent molecules by degassing method the porosity of the activated compound 1′ shows 39.8% accessible void space b.

Spectral CharacterizationOptical Characterization

In this study, the optical spectra of 1′ and I 2 @1′ (inset, a,b) were recorded from the deposited thin films in the range of 250–450 nm. The UV–vis spectrum of 1′ depicts strong absorption in the visible region at ∼340 nm, whereas I 2 @1′ absorbs at ∼360 nm. The TD-DFT calculations (with the singlet spin state) in DMSO using the CPCM model was tried to explain the origin of the UV–vis transition of 1′ and I 2 @1′. The calculated energies of selected transitions with oscillation strengths (f) and molecular orbitals (MOs) are listed in Table S3. The λcalc value for 1′ is 342.2 nm (LIodide → LINH), and that of I 2 @1′ main band appears at 338.8 nm with a shoulder at 358.5 nm (LINH → LIodide); these are referred to as the inter ligand charge transfer transitions (ILCT; ).

The p/p 0 position of the inflection point of the isotherm was evidently related to diameter, which was found to be typically in the mesopore range (2–50 nm), and the sharpness of the steps indicated the distribution of uniform mesopores, which was further confirmed by the pore size distribution plot using Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method as shown in Figure S3. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of the sample were 611 and 846 m2 g–1, respectively, with an average pore diameter of 14.7 nm and pore volume of 0.26 cm3 g–1, which is typical of microporous pore volume. Thus, gas adsorption studies clearly indicate the microporous and mesoporous features of 1′. The nature of mesoporosity having a pore diameter of 14.7 nm presumably originates from the interparticle voids, since the unit cell parameters are typically within the range of 2 nm, interpenetration in the framework structure presumably being the reason for the narrow aperture of the window. The high specific surface area with microporous and mesoporous features thus have prompted us to perform iodine (diameter being 4.94 Å) uptake study with 1′ in cyclohexane medium.
